Sample programs for some tasks

This code is meant to give you some inspiration for writing your homework. It’s not stuff you can lift and use in your assignments, and copying things directly out of this file is dangerous if you don’t understand how they work. (Of course, any code you copy from another source must be cited.) But reading and understanding how this code works will help you out quite a lot.

Checking to see if a number is a perfect square – the dumb way

There are far more efficient ways to do this, but this illustrates a couple of programming concepts.

 1 // We want to see if the number n is a perfect square
 2 int i; // i is usually used as a generic "counter" variable
 3 int is_square=0; // We’ll set this to 1 if the number 
 4                  // is a perfect square
 5 
 6 for (i=0;i<n;i++) // This could be made a lot faster, of course
 7 {
 8   if (i*i == n)
 9     is_square = 1; // Don’t need the squiggly braces if you only have 
10 }                  // one statement after the "if"
11 
12 if (is_square == 1)
13   printf("%d is a perfect square.\n",n);
14 else
15   printf("%d isn’t a perfect square.\n",n);

The key here is the use of a flag variable, in this case is_square: a variable that is equal to 1 if something has (or hasn’t) happened, and is zero otherwise. Here we set is_square to 0, and set it to 1 once we discover that the number is a perfect square.

Note that this is terrible programming for a lot of reasons. We could use break; to exit the loop once we’ve found that it’s square; break is a command that immediately breaks you out of a for loop. The point of showing this is that you will need a similar procedure to check numbers for prime-ness.

Printing a multiplication table

This illustrates the use of one for loop within another.

1 int i,j;
2 for (i=1;i<=12;i++) // because it’s ALWAYS twelve...
3 {
4   for (j=1;j<=12;j++) // What would "j<=i" do?
5   {
6     printf("%3d ",i*j); // "%3d" means "An integer, but
7   }                     // leave space for three digits"
8   printf("\n"); // skip a line after each row
9 }

Euler’s childhood assignment: adding the numbers from 1 to 100

1 int sum=0;    // note that we must set sum to zero 
2               // before we add things to it! 
3 int i;
4 
5 for (i=1; i<=100; i++)   // note that "i++" is shorthand for "i=i+1"
6   sum=sum+i;
7 
8 printf("The sum of numbers from 1 to 100 is %d\n",sum);

Tracking the motion of a falling body

Here, if we already know the analytic answer $x=\frac{1}{2}at^2$, we can just evaluate it. But what if we don’t know how to derive that?

Suppose something is falling from an initial height h, and we want to use time intervals of size dt. These variables are assumed to already be defined.

 1 double y=h,t=0,v=0;
 2 for(t=0; ;t += dt) // This loop will go forever! 
 3 {                  
 4   y += v *dt;    // in time dt, the body falls a distance v*dt, if dt is
 5                  // small enough that v is essentially constant
 6   v -= 9.8 * dt; // in time dt, the velocity decreases by g*dt
 7   printf("%f\t%f\n",t,y);
 8   if (y < 0)
 9     break; // if we’ve hit the ground, break out of the loop
10 
11 }
